job_title: Substance Use Counselor in Aloha, OR
pros: Excellent, diverse population of participants, with some very dedicated and competent clinicians. Medical benefits are generous. Training funds available to staff.
cons:
There is a VERY high turnover rate, even for a human services agency. Upper management is fractured and understaffed at best, and flippant at worst, with very little time or energy given to address real concerns that clinicians have. There is no proper outlet for these concerns to be addressed. It's bureaucracy without the tools in place to navigate it. Be careful bringing up anything that may point to larger institutional problems or ethical concerns, or they have no qualms with making you disappear without regard to continuity of care for the ones we serve. 

The lack of recognition and engagement leads many to finish their licensure or other credentials and find somewhere else to work (that is, when there is actually enough management to provide proper clinical supervision). Don't expect to be here for the long term, and those receiving services will ultimately be the ones who suffer from being shuttled around to different therapists and case managers.

I downplayed the other reviews on this site and accepted the job anyway. What they say is very real.

review_title: Great company with great work incentives and support.
pros: Sequoia Mental Health Services is a great company to work for. You get ample time off for vacation, sick days, and Holidays. They are flexible with allowing you to use PTO because they understand work/life balance is important in preventing burnout.  You get PTO for acquiring continued education in addition to reimbursement for continuing education (even if you're not licensed). Professional development is supported and encouraged by management.  Dress code is business casual and as long as you're modest you can dress modern/unique (including having colorful hair).  Colleagues are supportive and collaborative. There is no bullying that I have witnessed or retaliative behavior. The work environment is friendly and caring. It is also fast paced, which I enjoy because it is never boring. The health insurance, dental insurance, and vision insurance is great coverage if you are single. They are supportive of colleagues using FMLA should any illness arise, from what I have seen. Each month they provide all staff training to keep staff up to date with therapy modalities or changes occurring on state/county level that may effect clients. Overall I love working for this company. I appreciate the support from management, the work incentives, and how it doesn't feel like some large corporation.
cons: Too much concentration on the business model, from supervisors to line workers and not enough focus on providing treatment.

review_title: Best agency I have ever worked for - Very committed to client care
pros: Sequoia Mental Health is a very positive, supportive and appreciative environment to work in. Everyone, from management to direct care staff, are deeply committed to our clients and providing the best possible care. Staff have the ability to directly communicate their ideas and struggles to their Supervisor, the Clinical Director and the Executive Director. Community Mental Health is stressful and hard work and Sequoia has found a way to make it as supportive and positive as possible. I recommend Sequoia to anyone who wants to learn and grow as a clinician!
cons: There have been a lot of changes in the past year due to payment methodology that have been challenging for everyone. It is such a shame that a few people who have likely left or were let go say such inflammatory things against the agency that simply are not true. We have wonderful dedicated staff, many of whom have been here for years, as well as new clinicians bringing energy and enthusiasm to the teams at Sequoia. This site shows the old adage that most of the people who complain are people who have a beef or got in trouble because of poor performance.

pros: Nice building. Seems professional. Counselors and case managers are awesome hardworking caring people.
cons: High turnover in staff. Some leave voluntarily. Others fired. Staff turnover is more then 60%. Even if firings were for "cause" it causes extreme stress in employeea to have cubicle matea "just disappear" and not be able to find out why. Staff is told the employee knows it is coming and they can't discuss it due to confidentiality. But firings  and "disappearances" happen on a weekly basis on average.  Those who stay are told not to discuss "disappearances" or anything else. The clinical supervisor and most supervisors don't even say good morning. Doubt they are shamed. Probably more that they have personality disorders. There reactions might be truthful since you may be firing  you by y afternoon.  Very dehumanizing environment. . I'd think it it is a sign of the times, but the rate of turnover is extremely high. I wish there was some oversight by the board of directors, but they are invisible. I hope someone who is fired files a lawsuit. That is probably the only way to make change, unfortunately.  Clients and counselors/ case managers are just awesome but management is not.

review_title: Invaluable opportunity for mental health experience with irreplaceable coworkers cheering you on
pros:
I absolutely love working for Sequoia. The work is challenging and may be overwhelming at first. But if you’re able to stick through the first three months of navigating systems, policies, and personalities, you’re set to continue developing irreplaceable experience in a fun, fast-paced work environment. 

- Management has improved significantly since I’ve started working here. There are changes constantly being implemented to improve the structure of the agency. 

- Coworkers are awesome. With new management, Sequoia is doing a fantastic job at fizzling out lazier, unethical employees, and you’re left with a friendly, diverse coworkers who are always willing to help out as needed, and who really care about the work they do and the clients they serve.

- Relaxed atmosphere. You’ll find people from all breeds of life working here and you’re free to be yourself. It’s not a suit and tie, heavily micromanaged organization. 

- Bonus incentives for meeting productivity

- Allowed use of agency vehicles for community appointments - a lot of similar agencies don’t have this! 

- Generous PTO accrual and free healthcare 

- Flexible scheduling. Need to go to a doctor’s appointment? You can without the crippling anxieties of requesting PTO - go on your lunch break or at the start or at the end of your day. You have the freedom to flex your hours here, as long as you’re working at least an 8-hour day. Set your own schedule. 

- Supervision towards licensure 

- Monthly yoga 

- Team outings and company potlucks

- Excellent opportunity to learn about social service systems and community resources. 

- Upper management works hard to put the agency in a constant state of improvement 

- Of course, the clients are absolutely amazing. I feel so fortunate to be serving the people that I do, and the work is personally fulfilling.
cons:
- Training is disorganized and poorly structured, but this is being revamped

- Pay is less than other agencies 

- Salaried positions mean you can easily find yourself wrapped up in tasks and stay late, meaning there’s no overtime opportunities. 

- Forced to take PTO during agency closures (snow days). 

- Occasional lack of follow-up / follow through with upper management, but I attribute this to simple business or forgetfulness. This has improved vastly since I’ve started working here. 

- The work can be very emotionally taxing if you don’t implement enough self care into your life. 

- No room to advance within the agency

pros: There are wonderful clients at this agency, and staff care very much for their clients.
cons:
Oh my gosh where do I even start?  Hands down, Sequoia is the absolute worst company to work for.  I was offered a position and accepted, despite the terrible reviews on this site.  I thought, "well that won't happen to me."  I was wrong!  

1- Absolutely no training provided.  You are thrown to the wolves from day one.  Managers MIGHT introduce new employees around the office,  but usually do not.  This leaves new employees to blindly figure out who to talk to.

2- There is no consistency in management.  At all.  You can speak to three different managers in one day and get three entirely different answers to the same question.  They do not talk to each other and basically expect the employees to deliver messages to other managers.  

3- Snide remarks, rude behavior, talking badly about employees is a daily occurrence by management.  You will overhear conversations between management and employees that should be left behind closed doors.  Managers will literally come to your desk and ask what you think about other employees, while making fun of them.  If you think it hasn't happened to you personally, you're most likely wrong.  

4- Management DOES NOT have your back.  EVER.  They put up a good front, and say they will back you.   But the moment your back is turned they will strike, and make you look like the worst employee they've ever had.  

5- HR does NOT have your back either.  They are in cahoots with managers and will do anything they can to sabotage you, and destroy your work and reputation.  

6- Expect meetings about you to happen without you being there.  Several people will hold meetings about employees and won't invite the employee to explain anything.  

7- Extremely high turnover.  In my time there I can't even count how many employees quit or mysteriously disappeared from the office one day.  Even the Doctor's at Sequoia leave!  

8- Different expectations for people on the same team.  You will find yourself resenting coworkers because they will be treated much differently than you are.  

9- They will fire you at the drop of a hat.  You will not see it coming.  You will not have verbal or written warnings.  Nothing. 

10- If you are let go, and try to collect unemployment, expect them to fight you tooth and nail.  They will lie like mad to make it appear that you were an awful employee.  Keep records of EVERYTHING.  Every conversation you have with management get it in writing.  This will come in handy later when you try to defend yourself.  

I could go on, as there are many more negative things that happen in that agency. If I could give them zero stars, I would have.  I loved my job, I loved the clients, but I have nothing good to say about management.  


If you are thinking about working at Sequoia my advice is RUN!  RUN FAR FAR AWAY!
